text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.
-- Pilots' union at Air France to strike until Friday.
-- GEC Alsthom in talks to buy naval shipyard Leroux and Lotz specialised in high-speed boats.

-- CDR structure in charge of selling off Credit Lyonnais assets risks loss in sale of stake in Pinault Printemps Redoute. While the shares are valued on CDR's books at 3.6 billion francs, Pinault is expected to buy them as a block for 1.5 billion francs.
-- Total oil group seen in a position to win contract to 20-billion-francs South Pars gas development project in Iran, despite denying it has already signed a deal.
-- Socialist party leaders worried by public deficit, call for increased control and auditing of public deficits.
-- Job creations rose 0.1 percent in the first quarter.
-- French logistics and haulage firms Norbert Dentressangle and Giraud, as well as Britain's TDG, may be interested in buying Stockalliance.
-- Former Finance Minister Alain Madelin in an interview calls for increased decentralisation and greater freedom for small and medium-sized firms.
-- Compagnie Bancaire to launch a 2.26 billion francs securitized loan, backed by real-estate loans.
-- Traffic expected to return to normal on SNCF railways today, after a strike by conductors.
-- Court rules Banque Rivaud is to loan some 20 million francs to railway rolling stock manufacturer Remafer to avoid it filing for bankruptcy after the bank cut loans.
-- Most Air France flights maintained despite four-day pilots' strike starting today.
